title: Top Colleges in the West by Size
sub_head: Caltech, Stanford and USC are the region’s leaders for their size in the WSJ/THE College Rankings
body:
The highest-ranked small and midsize colleges in the West are both among the top 10 schools of any kind nationwide in the Wall Street Journal/Times Higher Education College Rankings, and the region’s top large colleges include five of the country’s top 10 public schools.
The WSJ/THE rankings are based on 15 factors across four main categories: Forty percent of each school’s overall score comes from student outcomes, including measures of graduate salaries and debt burdens, 30% from the school’s academic resources, including how much it spends on teaching, 20% from how well it engages its students and 10% from its environment, a measure of the diversity of its students and faculty.
Schools with fewer than 3,000 undergraduates are considered small in these rankings, those with 3,000 to 10,000 undergrads are midsize and those with more than 10,000 are large.
The top small college in the West is the California Institute of Technology, ranked No. 7 among all schools nationally. Two other small schools in the region are among the top 50 colleges nationally, Pomona College at No. 24 and Claremont McKenna College at No. 35.
The region’s top midsize school is Stanford University, ranked No. 4 among all schools in the country. The next-highest-ranked midsize school in the West is Santa Clara University, at No. 83 among all schools nationwide.
